results.title: Birth of Dawn
results.brief_description:
Hannah Brontë’s Birth of Dawn explores the cycle of life, birth, death and rebirth through the lens of the femme body. The sun, reimagined as a pregnant belly, symbolises the moment before new life enters the world. The work invites us to consider the Earth as a living, breathing body and questions how we move across it.

Set on a planet yet to experience its first dawn, this dreamscape merges ancient and futuristic landscapes, free from man-made objects. The inhabitants communicate through movement and telepathic frequencies projected through the soundscape. Having evolved beyond language, they experience every emotion that comes with growth – pain and pleasure ripple across each frame.

Birth of Dawn transports you into the present moment through bass-heavy waves, where past and future merge into one continuous cycle. There is no beginning or end here – only the infinite potential of new life and transformation.

There is nothing more science fiction than nature itself.

Created on the unceded lands of Yugambeh, Arakwal and Bundjalung Country

results.title: 'Pardon me for being born into a nation of racists' T-shirt
results.brief_description: “The slogan on the T-shirt was from a poster I had made during the 1971 South African Springbok rugby tour of Australia, which drew massive anti-apartheid demonstarations in Australia.” - Gary Foley

results.title: Rotted Luck
results.brief_description:
Rotted Luck envisions a slot machine overtaken by a living fungal network, playfully critiquing the addictive potential of gaming and gambling. The spinning reel displays familiar slot machine icons like cherries and lemons, but this game unfolds differently. The fruit spins uncontrollably and starts to decay as mould spreads across the screen. As you play, your movements are tracked through a cloud of spores that ultimately engulfs you.

Rotted Luck disrupts the usual interactivity and visual style of slot machines to encourage a stranger, shared and more joyful experience. By subverting conventional game mechanics, it proposes an outcome that isn’t about ‘winning’. Communal, non-addictive and movement-based, Rotted Luck favours the fun of play.

To create the piece, artists Vidya Rajan and Ian MacLarty studied slot machine design and imagined a fungus mistaking one for food. They photographed real decaying fruit, transformed them into 3D models, and used a common webcam to track player movements.

results.title: Model 621 Sound Projector with tripod and stand
results.credit_line: ACMI Collection. Tripod donated by Daryl Annett.
results.brief_description: In 1951, this projector was brought to the Koomooloo Station in South Australia to entertain workers during the shearing season.

constellations_primary.name: Bell & Howell Projector 621: This picture has been edited for content
constellations_primary.description: The Bell & Howell-Gaumont Model 621 projector was originally used entertain the shearers on a sheep farm in South Australia with the films screened sometimes edited for distribution.

results.title_for_label: Model 621 Sound Projector with tripod and stand
results.description: Though it was made in England, this projector made it over 15,000kms to the Koomooloo Station in South Australia. Situated on pastoral land in the Murray and Mellee region of South Australia, Koomooloo Station operated as a sheep station from 1868 and in 1951, this projector was bought to entertain workers during the shearing season. Luckily it has a vent at the back of the casing to keep it cool because if it was used inside a shearing shed the heat would’ve been insufferable.

results.title: British Mutoscope featuring Charlie Chaplin reel
results.brief_description: The mutoscope was an early motion-picture machine that worked like a flipbook. Instead of continuous prints in a book, the mutoscope’s cards were attached to a reel and the images were animated when you turned a hand crank, much like Thomas Edison’s Kinetoscope.

constellations_primary.name: Perception, time and flickering images
constellations_primary.description: Using a peep hole and a loop of rotating still images, mutoscopes control the point of view of the audience while also creating the illusion of depth. Filmmakers have since put optical tricks to work creating surreal scenes.

results.description: The mutoscope was an early motion-picture machine that worked like a flipbook. Instead of continuous prints in a book, the mutoscope’s cards were attached to a reel and the images were animated when you turned a hand crank, much like Thomas Edison’s Kinetoscope. It was also similar because it didn’t feature projection and only one person could view it at a time. Mutoscope scenes were silent (hence the name) and lasted for one minute. One of the machine’s most famous reels was What the Butler Saw, an early erotic film showing a woman partly undressing as if spied through a keyhole. This reel was so popular that the mutoscope was sometimes known as the ‘What the Butler Saw’ machine.
description_for_label: The mutoscope was an early motion-picture machine that worked like a flipbook. Instead of continuous prints in a book, the mutoscope’s cards were attached to a reel and the images were animated when you turned a hand crank, much like Thomas Edison’s Kinetoscope. It was also similar because it didn’t feature projection and only one person could view it at a time. Mutoscope scenes were silent (hence the name) and lasted for one minute. One of the machine’s most famous reels was What the Butler Saw, an early erotic film showing a woman partly undressing as if spied through a keyhole. This reel was so popular that the mutoscope was sometimes known as the ‘What the Butler Saw’ machine.
